results.title: Desert bloom
results.creator_credit: Eugene Corr, Michael Hausman and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in Las Vegas at the time of the first atom bomb tests in 1951, this powerful drama examines the life of a struggling middle-class Nevada family, seen through the eyes of 13 year old Rose Chismore (Annabeth Gish). Finding life difficult with her war-scarred father (Jon Voight), Rose forms a close bond with her flamboyant Aunt Starr (Ellen Barkin) whose friendship comes at a critical time.

results.title: Pal Joey
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Fred Kohlmar, George Sidney Productions and Essex
results.brief_description: Pal Joey, starring Frank Sinatra, Kim Novak and Rita Hayworth, is strong, funny entertainment based on a novel by John O’Hara. It features 14 songs from Rodgers and Hart including “The Lady is a Tramp”, “Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered” and “My Funny Valentine”. Sinatra is an out of heel nightclub singer, Joey Evans, who plays the field with women. He is ideal as the irreverent, glib Joey.

results.title: Des Enfants Gates = Spoiled Children
results.creator_credit: Bertrand Tavernier, Michel Piccoli and WDR La Sept Cinema
results.brief_description:
A famous director, unable to concentrate on his new script at home with his family, rents a flat in a high rise building. Instead of finding peace and quiet, he gets involved in the tenants’ fight against an exploitative landlord, and with a girl half his age.

Credits: Producers, Alain Sarde, Michel Piccoli, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Christine Pascal, Charlotte Dubreuil, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Alain Levent ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Christine Pascal, Michel Aumont, Gerard Jugnot, Arlette Bonnard, Genevieve Mnich, Thierry Lhermitte, Michel Blanc, Daniel Toscan du Plantier, Martin Lamotte.

results.title: Descent
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Giles Walker, Desmond Dew, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Descent is a film about David Murray, a member of Canada’s National Ski Team. It shows the less glamorous aspects of training for the World Cup Downhill race, the tension prior to the event, and Murray’s mixed feelings when it is all over. The camera records a spectacular slow-motion fall, and speeds that would not appeal to your average highway patrol. Murray comes across as a skillful, courageous and dedicated athlete, and a very likeable guy at that. Sound film without commentary. Film without words.

results.title: Dernier Atout = the Last Ace on the Deck
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker and Andre Halley des Fontaines
results.brief_description:
“As if he wasnt hamstrung enough by a Nazi Occupation looming over his shoulders, the ambitious Jacques Becker, sets his first film, an atmospheric crime saga in South America! Two police academy students are thrown into deep water when they decide to investigate a criminals death - complicating matters is their arch-rival’ s kid-sister who wants to help. Amazingly, the novice Becker is already a maestro and pulls it off.” Reference: The American Cinematheque. Online. http://www.americancinematheque.com/jacquesbecker99.htm

Credits: Producer, Andre H des Fontaines ; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Maurice Auberge, Pierre Bost, Louis Chavance ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Jean Alfaro ; art direction, Max Douy.
Cast: Raymond Roulau, Mireille Balin, Pierre Renoir, Georges Rollin, Noel Roquevert.

results.title: Derek Jarman's Blue
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, Takashi Asai, James MacKay and Basilisk Communications, Uplink
results.brief_description: Derek Jarman’s last film, made as he was dying from an AIDS related illness, is a devastating exploration of death and dying. Delivered in Jarman’s own voice-over, with assistance from Nigel Terry, Tilda Swinton and John Quentin, the film is a testimony to courage; it is also a farewell to love, and to life. By turns sad and exhilarating, the shimmering blue of the screen becomes a canvas across which the audience interacts with the essayist filmmaker. Jarman was one of the English-language world’s most daring, transgressive and experimental film artists and it is fitting that his last film continues his maverick’s love for exploration and the avant-garde. Right to the end, his wit and intelligence were undiminished. NOTE: VISUALS CONSIST OF BLUE SCREEN

results.title: Panorama: the state wide screen [excerpts No. 1]
results.brief_description: Excerpts from the Panorama documentary on the State Film Centre of Victoria. Candid footage of the goings on at the S.F.C.V. in Carlton in the early sixties. Customer service, despatch operations, film retrieving, checking and cleaning, and free film screenings in urban and rural areas.
results.description: Excerpts from the Panorama documentary on the State Film Centre of Victoria. Candid footage of the goings on at the S.F.C.V. in Carlton in the early sixties. results.title: Pandora
results.creator_credit: Derek May, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Experimental filmmaker Derek May and colour cameraman Martin Duckworth collaberated here in a surrealistic retelling of the old myth. A film of technical experiment with forceful, colourful effect and creative use of shadows.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek May, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Panasonic VHS-C Movie Camera NV-A1
results.brief_description: The Panasonic VHS-C Movie Camera NV-A1 was a condensed VHS (Video Home System) videocassette format, which was mainly used in consumer-grade camcorders. It was a smaller size than VHS, as with Betamax, but could be played in a standard VCR with an adaptor.
results.description: Various magnetic tape technologies were produced during the period of the videotape format wars during the late 1970s and early 80s, which was particularly significant for the amateur filmmaker market. Cameras became more and more compact, making them cheaper and portable. The Panasonic VHS-C Movie Camera NV-A1 was a condensed VHS (Video Home System) videocassette format, which was mainly used in consumer-grade camcorders. It was a smaller size than VHS, as with Betamax, but could be played in a standard VCR with an adaptor making the footage easier to access than ever before.
